context: [6] The inhibitory effect of AVG on ethylene production was observed within 24 h of the initial imbibition. [7] Overall, when imbibed with water for 72 h, PI and NIL-PI seeds had the highest total ethylene production at 2,310 and 1,860 ÂµL mgâˆ’1 at 32Â°C, while Sal and NIL-Sal seeds produced less than half as much ethylene at their germination temperature threshold (29Â°C), 900 and 815 ÂµL mgâˆ’1, respectively (Supplemental Table S6). [8] However, when imbibed with 10 mm AVG, the total ethylene production for all genotypes was reduced to approximately 200 ÂµL mgâˆ’1, similar to that for water-imbibed seeds at thermoinhibitory temperatures (Supplemental Table S6). [1] These tests showed that AVG-treated seeds of all genotypes would have similar low levels of endogenous ethylene production prior to being exposed to different concentrations of exogenous ethylene to test their sensitivity to ethylene perception and signaling. [2] When exposed to different ethylene concentrations (0.01, 0.1, 1, and 10 Î¼L Lâˆ’1) after pretreatment with 10 mm AVG for 24 h, both PI and NIL-PI seeds were able to germinate in the presence of 1 Î¼L Lâˆ’1 ethylene at 32Â°C (Fig. 4B). [3] In contrast, no germination was observed in Sal and NIL-Sal seeds that were exposed to 1 Î¼L Lâˆ’1 ethylene at 29Â°C, and 10 Î¼L Lâˆ’1 ethylene was required to recover full germination (Fig. 4B). [4] Germination recovery of NIL-PI seeds was intermediate, with 50% germination at 1 Î¼L Lâˆ’1 ethylene and 83% germination at 10 Î¼L Lâˆ’1 ethylene.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, ethene is linked to signal transduction through its role in regulating seed germination. The study examines how ethylene production, influenced by AVG treatment, affects the sensitivity of different seed genotypes to ethylene concentrations. This indicates that ethylene acts as a signaling molecule, triggering germination processes in response to environmental cues.
llm_generation.reason: The score of 4 reflects a significant connection between ethene and signal transduction, as ethylene is shown to play a crucial role in the signaling pathways that regulate seed germination, supported by experimental data on ethylene sensitivity in various seed genotypes.
